conclusion: Understanding the problem involves static equilibrium of two hemispheres between walls.

Two hemispheres A and B with masses m and 2m respectively, hemisphere A is in contact with the left wall with friction, hemisphere B is in contact with the right wall smooth, the line connecting their centers makes a 30° angle with the horizontal.
The hemispheres are just on the verge of slipping, need to find the coefficient of dynamic friction between hemisphere A and the left wall.

Identify all forces acting on each hemisphere: For hemisphere A - Weight: mg, Normal force from left wall: F_N, Friction force from left wall: F_f, Contact force from hemisphere B: F_AB; For hemisphere B - Weight: 2mg, Normal force from right wall: F_N1, Contact force from hemisphere A: F_BA = -F_AB.
Contact force between the hemispheres acts along the line connecting their centers, decomposed into components: Horizontal component: F_AB·cos(30°), Vertical component: F_AB·sin(30°).
Set up equilibrium equations for hemisphere A: Horizontal direction - F_N = F_AB·cos(30°), Vertical direction - F_f = mg + F_AB·sin(30°).
Set up equilibrium equations for hemisphere B: Horizontal direction - F_N1 = F_AB·cos(30°), Vertical direction - F_AB·sin(30°) = 2mg.
Solve for the contact force: F_AB = 4mg.
Find the normal force on hemisphere A: F_N = 3.464mg.
Find the friction force on hemisphere A: F_f = 3mg.
Calculate the coefficient of friction: μ = 0.866.
The coefficient of dynamic friction between hemisphere A and the left wall is 0.866.
